name: Rosetta Stone
relevance: Enabled decipherment of Egyptian hieroglyphics, unlocking Egyptian records that reference biblical peoples and events.

name: Merneptah Stele
relevance: Earliest known extra-biblical reference to 'Israel' (c. 1208 BC). Pharaoh Merneptah claims to have defeated Israel in Canaan.
note: The determinative used for Israel indicates a people, not a land — suggesting Israel was already an established entity.

name: Tel Dan Stele
relevance: Contains the phrase 'House of David' (bytdwd) — the first extra-biblical reference to King David. Dates to c. 841 BC.
note: Erected by Hazael of Aram-Damascus, boasting of his victory over kings of Israel and Judah.

name: Moabite Stone (Mesha Stele)
relevance: King Mesha of Moab describes his revolt against Israel, confirming 2 Kings 3. Mentions the 'House of David' and the God of Israel (YHWH).
note: Also references Omri king of Israel and the tribe of Gad.

name: Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III
relevance: Shows King Jehu of Israel (or his ambassador) bowing before Assyrian king Shalmaneser III. Only known depiction of a biblical king.
note: The inscription reads: 'Tribute of Jehu, son of Omri' (the Assyrians continued calling Israel 'House of Omri').

name: Sennacherib's Prism (Taylor Prism)
relevance: Sennacherib's own account of his 701 BC campaign confirms 2 Kings 18–19. He boasts of shutting up Hezekiah 'like a caged bird' but never claims to have taken Jerusalem.
note: The silence about capturing Jerusalem is consistent with the biblical account of divine deliverance.

name: Siloam Inscription
relevance: Commemorates the completion of Hezekiah's tunnel (2 Kings 20:20), describing how two teams of tunnelers met in the middle.

name: Lachish Letters
relevance: Military correspondence from the last days of Judah (c. 588–586 BC), written as Babylon was conquering Judean cities. Confirms Jeremiah's account.
note: Letter IV reads: 'We are watching for the fire signals of Lachish...for we cannot see Azekah' — Azekah had already fallen (cf. Jer 34:7).

name: Cyrus Cylinder
relevance: Cyrus the Great's decree allowing exiled peoples to return home and rebuild their temples. Confirms Ezra 1:1–4.
note: Isaiah 45:1 names Cyrus as God's 'anointed' (mashiach) — written ~150 years before Cyrus was born.

name: Dead Sea Scrolls
location: Shrine of the Book, Israel Museum
relevance: Over 900 manuscripts including every OT book except Esther. Pushed OT manuscript evidence back 1,000 years and confirmed remarkable textual preservation.
note: The Great Isaiah Scroll (1QIsaᵃ) is virtually identical to the Masoretic text written 1,000 years later.

name: Pilate Stone
relevance: Limestone inscription reading '[Pon]tius Pilatus, Prefect of Judaea' — confirms the historicity of the Roman governor who tried Jesus.

name: Caiaphas Ossuary
relevance: Ornate bone box inscribed 'Yehosef bar Qayafa' (Joseph son of Caiaphas) — likely the high priest who presided over Jesus' trial.

name: James Ossuary
relevance: Aramaic inscription reads 'James, son of Joseph, brother of Jesus.' If authentic, it's the earliest physical reference to Jesus outside the Bible.
note: Authenticity debated. Owner Oded Golan was acquitted of forgery in 2012, but the IAA remains skeptical of the 'brother of Jesus' portion.

name: Galilee Boat ('Jesus Boat')
relevance: A 1st-century fishing boat preserved in mud, exactly the type used by Jesus and his disciples on the Sea of Galilee.

name: Pool of Siloam
location: In situ, City of David, Jerusalem
relevance: The pool where Jesus healed the blind man (John 9:7). Excavated and found to be a large, stepped ritual pool from the Second Temple period.

name: Pool of Bethesda
location: In situ, Jerusalem (near St. Anne's Church)
relevance: The pool with five porticoes where Jesus healed a paralyzed man (John 5:2). Exactly matches John's description of a pool with five covered colonnades.
note: Critics once said John invented this detail. Excavations confirmed a trapezoid-shaped double pool with five porticoes.

name: Nazareth Inscription
relevance: A Roman decree imposing the death penalty for tomb robbery — possibly a reaction to claims of Jesus' resurrection.
note: Recent analysis dates the marble to Kos, not Nazareth. May still reflect Roman awareness of empty-tomb claims.

name: Ketef Hinnom Silver Scrolls
relevance: Two tiny silver scrolls with the Priestly Blessing (Numbers 6:24–26). The oldest known texts of the Hebrew Bible, predating the Dead Sea Scrolls by 400 years.

name: Babylonian Chronicles
relevance: Confirm Nebuchadnezzar's siege and capture of Jerusalem in 597 BC and provide dating for key biblical events.

name: Nebo-Sarsekim Tablet
relevance: Mentions 'Nabu-sharrussu-ukin, chief eunuch' of Nebuchadnezzar — the same official named in Jeremiah 39:3 (Nebo-Sarsekim).

name: Arch of Titus
relevance: Depicts Roman soldiers carrying the Temple menorah and sacred objects after the destruction of Jerusalem in 70 AD.

name: LMLK Seal Impressions
relevance: Royal seal impressions reading 'Belonging to the King' (LMLK), found on storage jars from Hezekiah's reign — evidence of centralized preparation for Sennacherib's invasion.

name: Bulla of Baruch son of Neriah
relevance: Clay seal impression reading 'Belonging to Berekhyahu son of Neriyahu the scribe' — Baruch, Jeremiah's scribe.
note: A second bulla found by Eilat Mazar in controlled excavation at the Ophel (2005) bears the same name.

name: Hezekiah's Royal Bulla
relevance: Seal impression reading 'Belonging to Hezekiah [son of] Ahaz, King of Judah' — first seal of an Israelite/Judean king found in controlled excavation.
note: Discovered by Eilat Mazar's team in a stratified context at the foot of the Temple Mount's southern wall.

name: House of David Inscription (Mesha Stele)
relevance: New high-resolution imaging of the Mesha Stele revealed 'House of David' in line 31, providing a second 9th-century BC reference to David's dynasty.
note: Published by Lemaire (1994), confirmed by Langlois (2019) using Reflectance Transformation Imaging.

name: City of David Excavations
relevance: Continuous excavations have revealed structures from the time of David and Solomon, Hezekiah's water systems, First Temple period seals, and destruction layers matching 586 BC.

name: Erastus Inscription
relevance: A pavement inscription reading 'Erastus, in return for his aedileship, laid this pavement at his own expense' — likely the same Erastus Paul mentions in Romans 16:23.

name: Crucified Man of Giv'at ha-Mivtar
relevance: Skeleton of a crucified man (Yehohanan) with an iron nail still through his heel bone — the only direct archaeological evidence of Roman crucifixion.
note: Confirms that crucifixion victims could receive proper burial, consistent with the Gospels' account of Jesus' burial.

name: Magdala Stone
relevance: A carved stone block from a 1st-century synagogue in Mary Magdalene's hometown, featuring the earliest known depiction of the Second Temple menorah.

name: Tel Lachish Destruction Layer
relevance: Massive destruction layer from 701 BC confirming Sennacherib's siege. Assyrian reliefs at Nineveh depict this exact siege in extraordinary detail.
note: Sennacherib was so proud of conquering Lachish that he decorated an entire room of his palace with reliefs of the siege.
